qas.question: When does a great diversity of angiosperms appear in the fossil record?
What is the appearance of a large amount of angiosperms in the fossil record known as?
When did the division of the eight main groups of angiosperms occur?
What were the angiosperms up to by the late Cretaceous?
Beech and maple had already appeared by what period?

plausible_answers.text: in the mid-Cretaceous (approximately 100 million years ago)

qas.question: When does a diversity of magnoliids appear in the fossil record?
What is the appearance of ferns in the fossil record called?

plausible_answers.text: environments formerly occupied by ferns and cycadophytes

qas.question: By the end of the Tertiary, what did angiosperms dominate?

plausible_answers.text: close to the end of the Cretaceous 66 million years ago

qas.question: When did eudicots replace conifers as dominant trees?
When had eight main groups of Chloranthaceae recognizable as belonging to modern families appear?

context: The <a1_0><b6_0>great angiosperm radiation<b6_0/>,<a1_0/> when a great diversity of angiosperms appears in the fossil record, occurred <b5_0>in the mid-Cretaceous (<a0_0>approximately 100 million years ago<a0_0/>)<b5_0/>. However, a study in 2007 estimated that the division of the five most recent (the genus Ceratophyllum, the family Chloranthaceae, the eudicots, the magnoliids, and the monocots) of the eight main groups occurred around 1<a2_0>40 million years ago<a2_0/>. By the late Cretaceous, angiosperms appear to have <a3_0>dominated <b7_0>environments<a3_0/> formerly occupied by ferns and cycadophytes<b7_0/>, but large canopy-forming trees replaced conifers as the dominant trees only <b8_0>close to the end of the Cretaceous 66 million years ago<b8_0/> or even later, at the beginning of the Tertiary. The radiation of herbaceous angiosperms occurred much later. Yet, many fossil plants recognizable as belonging to modern families (including beech, oak, maple, and magnolia) had already appeared <b9_0>by the late <a4_0>Cretaceous<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
